key_work.title: Spotlights: Gillian Armstrong
key_work.brief_description: An Australian feature film and documentary director who specialises in period drama. Her films often feature female perspectives and protagonists. Gillian discusses female directors and also mentions My Brilliant Career (1979), which features in the New Wave section of Moving Australia.

constellations_other.name: Australians on the world stage
constellations_other.description: George Miller’s Mad Max revolutionised movies when it tore through cinemas in 1979. Max Rockatansky’s journey dispensing justice across the wasteland in his V8 Interceptor became a cult classic and catapulted Australian cinema onto the world stage.

links.description: My Brilliant Career was a brilliant start for Armstrong’s own career, with her first feature garnering Palm d’Or and Academy Award noms. It sticks to the feminist spirit of the Miles Franklin’s novel on which it’s based by featuring many women in key creative roles.

links.description: With the 1994 version of Little Women beloved by many, fans wondered what Armstrong made of Greta Gerwig’s remake. Taking too Twitter, the Australian director praised it’s “brave new structure” and “fantastic cast”, calling it “Little Women for this generation”.

links.description: Judy Davis earned two BAFTA awards forher breakout role in My Brilliant Career. links.description: After gaining rave reviews in Sharp Objects, Eliza Scanlen appeared in Gerwig’s Little Women. In the same year, she was the lead in Shannon Murphy’s debut coming-of-age dramedy Baby Teeth, which like Armstrong’s first feature, received rave reviews and film fest nominations.
